#Text=Make Kataif
#Text=Kataif , typically eaten during the month of Ramadan , is a Middle Eastern sweet that can be made in a number of ways .
#Text=Kataif is eaten in many of the countries in the Middle East but mostly in Palestine , Syria , Jordan , and Lebanon .
#Text=The recipe below provides a few ways to create these tasty sweets .
#Text=Perfect dessert for those celebrating Ramadan and for those who simply enjoy trying Middle Eastern desserts .
#Text=Quantity:12-15
#Text=Time to make:30-40 min
#Text=Ingredients
#Text=Batter
#Text=1/3 cups of all purpose flour
#Text=1 cup of semolina
#Text=1/2 teaspoon of yeast
#Text=1/3 cup of sugar
#Text=1/3 cup of pancake mix ( Aunt Jemimah pancake mix compete )
#Text=1 cup of water
#Text=1/2 teaspoon Mahlab spice
#Text=Filling
#Text=1/2 1 Ib .
#Text=block of sweet cheese
#Text=2 cups of toasted almonds
#Text=1 tablespoon of sugar
#Text=2 teaspoons of cinnamon
#Text=1/4 teaspoon of cardamon
#Text=Syrup
#Text=2 cups of sugar
#Text=1 cups of water
#Text=2 tablespoons of lemon water
#Text=1 teaspoon of rosewater
#Text=Steps
#Text=Find a clean surface .
#Text=Make sure to work in an environment that is clean and spacious so that nothing gets dirty and messy .
#Text=Prepare the batter .

#Text=Get a blender and place the 1/3 cups of flour , 1 cup of semolina , 1/2 teaspoon of ground mahlab , 1/2 teaspoon of yeast , 1/3 cup of sugar , 1/3 cup of pancake mix , and 1 cup of water ( may require 1/2 a cup more until the batter becomes smooth ) into it .
#Text=Blend the batter until it gets smooth .
#Text=Heat frying pan .
#Text=pour the mix i a large bowl and allow the it to rest for 10-15 minutes while the pan heats up .
#Text=Make sure it is on medium to low heat and that the batter is covered .
#Text=Pour the mix .
#Text=Once to batter has rested , use a ladle and pour about 1/4 cup onto the frying pan .
#Text=Notice that the kataif will start to bubble around the edges and soon will start to cover the entire surface .
#Text=If it is not covered with bubbles , then that means that the batter is too thick .
#Text=if that is the case add small quantities of water , whisk and try again .
#Text=Remove the kataif .
#Text=When it is no longer shiny and liquidy , then they are ready to be removed from the pan .
#Text=NOTE : cooking them over high heat will cause them to get burnt quickly and will dry them out .
#Text=That will cause them to split when they are filled or will reopen .
#Text=you want to color to be a golden brown so check with the first one , if its too dark , lower the heat and try again .
#Text=if it is too light , brig the heat up a little .
#Text=,
#Text=Cover them with a towel .
#Text=Take the kataif off the heat and immediately cover them with a kitchen towel or a light blanket .
#Text=THIS IS VERY IMPORTANT !
#Text=Covering them allows the kataif to remain soft and easy to stuff and seal without worrying about it splitting .
#Text=NOTE : if you do not cover the kataif they will dry out and the results will be that it will no longer seal and it will begin to split .
#Text=Prepare the fillings .
#Text=Take 1/2 block of 1 Ib . white sweet cheese and begin shredding it with a shredder into a plate until you feel is enough for the portion .
#Text=An alternative filling is ricotta :

#Text=Take 2 cups of toasted almonds/walnuts that are chopped or crushed , 1 tablespoon of sugar , 2 teaspoons of cinnamon , and 1/4 teaspoon of cardamon and place them into a small mixing bowl and mix them .
#Text=Stuff the kataif .
#Text=To stuff the kataif , place about 1-2 teaspoons of the desired filling into the middle of the kataif and fold it in half .
#Text=At this point it should look like a half moon .
#Text=Then begin to seal the edges by pinching them , with your thumb and index , tightly together .
#Text=once sealed , place them back under the covers and begin working on the syrup .
#Text=Make sure you do n't over stuff them because that may cause them to burst open during cooking .
#Text=,
#Text=,
#Text=Making the Syrup .
#Text=Take 1 cup of sugar , 3/4 cup of water , and 1 teaspoon of lemon juice and placed them in a pot to boil .
#Text=once it has reached its boiling point , lower the heat and let it simmer for 5 minutes
#Text=After simmering is done , turn off the heat totally and add 1 teaspoon of rosewater .
#Text=Some people replace the rosewater with cinnamon or orange peel .
#Text=Frying the Kataifi .
#Text=Grab a pot and pour about 2-3 cups of vegetable oil in it and turn on the heat , once the oil begins to boil , place the 2 or 3 kataif into the pot at a time and fry it util
#Text=the edges become crisp and golden brown .
#Text=NOTE : Baking the kataif is another method .
#Text=brush the kataif wit melted butter or vegetable oil and arrange them on a blanket sheet .
#Text=Bake them in a preheated oven at 200C until golden and crisp .
#Text=Soak with syrup .
#Text=Once the kataif is finished being fried or bakes , take it and quickly dunk them into the syrup and then arrange them on a serving plate .
#Text=NOTE : do not dunk them for more than a few seconds of else they will become soggy and soft .
#Text=Make tea .
#Text=In most middle eastern cultures , it is traditionally eaten with tea .
#Text=Take a tea pot and fill it up with water .
#Text=When you see that the water has boiled , place two bags of Lipton black tea and either a handful of mint leaves or sage ( maramia ) .
#Text=Turn off immediately and let it brew for about 5 min .
#Text=Once it has finished , pour in into a cup with about 2 teaspoons of sugar and enjoy it with kataif .
